Remember that tiny hooks catch additional fish than huge ones. Several writers are taught that the strange or extreme their opening line, the additional possible they're to “hook” the reader. By starting, I presume you mean how do I begin writing a story? It’s always hard. So I’ve found that the best way to deal with it is not to worry about it too much and just start typing. Sometimes ideas flow quickly, but often I have to write for a long time before I really figure out what I’m trying to say. Once I get words down on the page, I can begin to make sense of things, but it is always hard. In fact, let me repeat that: writing is always hard. There are some days when it flows easier than others, but mostly it is a kind of slog that somehow results in moments of enlightenment that surprises me as much as my reader. If by how do I start a story you mean how I write what journalists call a lede, that is a different question. I write mostly long-from narrative journalism, so for me, figuring out the lede often has to do with a character or an idea. I need to draw the reader in and establish quickly what the story is about and where it is going. Often I will chose a particular anecdote that is compelling, or a sentence that establishes a particular tone or expectation for the reader. In my memoir about growing up in Silicon Valley, I started with the sentence, “As a kid, I always felt lucky.” I like that because it established a central fact of my life, but also telegraphed to reader that, in the course of this narrative, my luck was likely to change. In The Water Will Come, I began with the sentence, “After the hurricane hit Miami in 2037, a foot of sand covered the famous bow-tie floor in the lobby of the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach.” Obviously the idea here was portray the consequences of sea level rise in a dramatic narrative of the future, one that not only set up the themes to be discussed in the book, but also was a kind of homage to the famous opening scene in Rachel Carson’s Silent Spring, in which she imagines a future spring day without birds.
